revisions.rev:
{{Infobox musical artist | name = Yeah Yeah Yeahs | image = Yeah Yeah Yeahs.jpg | caption = Yeah Yeah Yeahs in 2002. From left to right: [[Brian Chase]], [[Karen O]] and [[Nick Zinner]]. | landscape = yes | background = group_or_band | alias = | origin = [[New York City]], [[New York]], [[United States]] | genre = [[Indie rock]], [[art punk]], [[dance punk]], [[post-punk revival]] | years_active = {{Start date|2000}}âpresent | label = [[Interscope Records|Interscope]], [[Fiction Records|Fiction]], [[Modular Recordings|Modular]], [[Polydor Records|Polydor]] | associated_acts = [[Native Korean Rock]], [[Head Wound City]] | website = {{URL|www.yeahyeahyeahs.com}} | current_members = [[Karen O]]
[[Nick Zinner]]
[[Brian Chase]] }} '''Yeah Yeah Yeahs''' are an American [[indie rock]] band formed in [[New York City]] in 2000. The group is composed of vocalist and pianist [[Karen O]], guitarist and keyboardist [[Nick Zinner]], and drummer [[Brian Chase]].{{cite web|last=Phares |first=Heather |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/yeah-yeah-yeahs-p522831/biography |title=Yeah Yeah Yeahs |publisher=AllMusic |date=2002-05-17 |accessdate=2011-10-09}} They are complemented in live performances by second guitarist [[David Pajo]], who joined as a touring member in 2009 and replaced [[Imaad Wasif]] who had previously held this role. According to an interview that aired during the ABC network's ''Live from [[Central Park SummerStage]]'' series, the band's name was taken from modern New York City [[vernacular]]. The band has recorded three studio albums; the first, ''[[Fever to Tell]]'', was released in 2003. The second, ''[[Show Your Bones]]'', was released in 2006 and was named the second best album of the year by ''[[NME]]''. Their third studio album, ''[[It's Blitz!]]'', was released on 31 March 2009 in the USA and on 6 April 2009 in the rest of the world. ==History== ===Formation (2000â2002)=== [[Karen O]] and [[Brian Chase]] first met as students at [[Oberlin College]] in Ohio in the late '90s, where Chase was a [[jazz]] student at the conservatory. Karen then transferred to [[New York University]], and while in New York met [[Nick Zinner|Zinner]] in a local bar, where they formed an "instant connection". During this time they also shared a loft in Manhattan with future members of the band [[Metric (band)|Metric]].{{cite web|url=http://ladygunn.com/music/emily-haines-of-metric-interview |title=YYYs shared a loft with Metric |publisher=Ladygunn.com |date= |accessdate=2011-10-09}} The two formed an acoustic duo called "Unitard", but soon decided to "shake things up a bit" by forming a "trashy, punky, grimy" band modeled after the art student, [[avant-punk]] bands Karen O. was exposed to at Oberlin. {{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/2006/feb/26/popandrock.yeahyeahyeahs|title=Lynsey Hansley talks to Yeah Yeah Yeahs| first=Lynsey| last=Hanley| date=February 26, 2006| work=[[The Guardian]]| accessdate=2009-04-15}} After the drummer they recruited initially bowed out, Chase joined the line-up. The band wrote a slew of songs at their first rehearsal and soon wound up supporting [[The Strokes]] and [[The White Stripes]], earning a significant buzz for their arty and garage punk scene. In late 2001, the Yeah Yeah Yeahs released their [[Yeah Yeah Yeahs (EP)|self-titled debut EP]], which they recorded with [[Boss Hog]]'s Jerry Teel, on their own Shifty label.{{cite web| url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/Jerry+Teel| title=Jerry Teel| work=[[Discogs]]|accessdate=2009-04-15}} Early the next year the band stepped into the international spotlight, appearing at [[South by Southwest]], touring the U.S. with [[Girls Against Boys]] and Europe with [[Jon Spencer Blues Explosion]], and headlining their own U.K. tour. [[Wichita Recordings]] distributed the group's EP in the U.K. and [[Touch and Go Records|Touch and Go]] reissued it in the States.{{cite web| url=http://www.mtv.com/music/artist/yeah_yeah_yeahs/artist.jhtml| title=Yeah Yeah Yeahs| work=mtv.com| publisher=MTV| accessdate=2009-04-15}} ===''Fever To Tell'' (2003â2004)=== In 2003, the band released their debut album, ''[[Fever to Tell]]'', which received several strong critical reviews and sold more than 750,000 copies worldwide. The album's third single, "[[Maps (song)|Maps]]", received significant airplay on [[alternative music|alternative]] radio. In 2010, Rolling Stone ranked "[[Maps (song)|Maps]]" as 386th in their list of the 500 Greatest Songs of All Time. The video for their 2004 single "[[Y Control]]" was directed by [[Spike Jonze]]. In October 2004, the band released their first [[DVD]], ''[[Tell Me What Rockers to Swallow]]''. The DVD included a [[concert]] filmed at [[The Fillmore]] in [[San Francisco]], all of the band's music videos to date, and various interviews. In November 2009, the [[NME]] rated ''Fever to Tell'' the #5 Best Album of the Decade.{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/news/the-strokes/48412 |title=The Strokes' 'Is This It' tops NME albums of the decade list |accessdate=2009-11-17 |date=November 17, 2009 |work=NME News |publisher=[[NME]]}} ===''Show Your Bones'' (2005-2006)=== [[Image:Karen O, Tim Festival.jpg|thumb|upright|Karen O live at the Tim Festival in 2006]] Their second album, ''[[Show Your Bones]]'', was released on 27â28 March 2006. [[Karen O]] told [[online zine]] [[Drowned in Sound]], "''[[Show Your Bones]]'' is what happens when you put your finger in a light socket," crediting "9 year old antigenius wonder-kid Drake Barrett for the insight."{{cite news|first=Colin |last=Roberts |url=http://drownedinsound.com/news/562122 |title=Yeah Yeah Yeahs LP and single details, yeah |work=[[Drowned In Sound]] |date=January 11, 2006 |accessdate=2008-11-19}} The first single from the album, "[[Gold Lion]]", was released on 20 March 2006, reaching number 18 in the [[Official UK Singles Chart]]. It has been noted by Leah Greenblatt that "[[Gold Lion]]" sounds startlingly similar to "No New Tale To Tell" from 1980s alternative band [[Love and Rockets (band)|Love and Rockets]].{{cite news|last=Greenblatt |first=Leah |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,1204700,00.html |title=Did The Red Hot Chili Peppers copy Tom Petty? |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |date=June 16, 2006 |issue=883 |accessdate=2008-11-19}} The band toured throughout [[Europe]] and the [[United States]] during much of 2006, and also helped to curate an edition of the British [[All Tomorrow's Parties (music festival)|All Tomorrow's Parties]] festival. In December 2006, the album was named the second best album of the year by ''[[NME]]'' magazine, as well as "Cheated Hearts" being voted the 10th best song. ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine named it the 44th best album of 2006, while ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]'' magazine ranked it number 31 on their 40 best albums of 2006. ===''Is Is'' EP (2007)=== Yeah Yeah Yeahs' third EP, titled ''[[Is Is]]'', was released on 24 July 2007. It includes 5 previously unreleased songs and a short film, which was recorded and filmed at the GlassLands Gallery in Brooklyn, NY. The songs were written in 2004, during the Fever To Tell tour, and performed live often.{{cite news|url=http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/news/43606-yeah-yeah-yeahs-to-release-new-ep-of-old-songs|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20080307024159/http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/news/43606-yeah-yeah-yeahs-to-release-new-ep-of-old-songs|archivedate=2008-03-07|title=Yeah Yeah Yeahs to Release New EP of Old Songs|last=Maher|first=Dave|date=July 13, 2006|work=Pitchfork|accessdate=2009-09-17}} Three of the five tracks were featured on the "[[Tell Me What Rockers to Swallow]]" DVD. [[File:Yeah Yeah Yeahs at Glastonbury 2009.jpg|thumb|right|Karen O and Nick Zinner performing at the [[Glastonbury Festival]] 2009]] ===''It's Blitz!'' (2008â2009)=== The next album by the band was released in March 2009 and is titled ''[[It's Blitz!]]''.{{cite web|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/34436-new-yeah-yeah-yeahs-album-iits-blitzi/|title=New Yeah Yeah Yeahs Album: It's Blitz| date=January 21, 2009| work=[[Pitchfork Media]]| author=Breihan, Tom| accessdate=2009-04-15}} The band says the album sounds different from their previous ones but "still [sounds] like Yeah Yeah Yeahs". The album was originally set to be released 13 April, but following the [[internet leak|leak]] to the Internet on 22 February{{cite web| url=http://diditleak.co.uk/?paged=2| title=diditleak.co.uk| accessdate=2009-04-15}} the band's label, Interscope, pulled the release date closer to reduce the impact of the online leak.{{cite web| url=http://www.nme.com/news/yeah-yeah-yeahs/43188| title=Yeah Yeah Yeahs to release album early due to leak| date=March 3, 2009| work=[[NME]] |accessdate=2009-04-15}} The album spawned three singles: "[[Zero (Yeah Yeah Yeahs song)|Zero]]", "[[Heads Will Roll (song)|Heads Will Roll]]" and "[[Skeletons (Yeah Yeah Yeahs song)|Skeletons]]". ''It's Blitz!'' was named as the second best of 2009 by ''[[Spin Magazine]]'' and third best of 2009 by ''[[NME]]'' along with "[[Zero (Yeah Yeah Yeahs song)|Zero]]" from the album listed as the best track of the year by both.{{cite web|url=http://www.spin.com/gallery/40-best-albums-2009?page=39|title=The 40 Best Albums of 2009|date=December 7, 2009|work=Spin|accessdate=17 December 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/list/50-best-albums-of-2009/159978/|title=50 Best Albums of 2009|work=NME|accessdate=13 December 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/list/50-best-tracks-of-2009/159979|title=50 Best Tracks of 2009|work=NME|accessdate=13 December 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.spin.com/articles/20-best-songs-2009|title=The 20 Best Songs of 2009|author=Spin Staff|date=December 7, 2009|work=Spin|accessdate=17 December 2009}} ==Music style== Their style has been described as "an art-rock trio who made an edgy post-punk, dancefloor-friendly racket that mixed up [[Blondie (band)|Blondie]] with [[Siouxsie and the Banshees]]."{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/music/article6485717.ece|title=Yeah Yeah Yeahs: why fans of the art-punk trio can't say no|last=McLean|first=Craig|date=June 13, 2009|work=Times Online|accessdate=2 January 2010}} ==Touring== Alongside performing headlining tours across the world, the band has supported artists such as [[BjÃ¶rk]], [[The White Stripes]], [[The Strokes]], [[Liars (band)|Liars]], and [[Jon Spencer Blues Explosion]]. The band became one of the first western rock acts to play in [[China]] when they headlined the [[Modern Sky Festival]] in Beijing in 2007.{{cite news | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/25/arts/music/25sisa.html|title=For All the Rock in China|last=Sisario|first=Ben|date=2007-11-25|accessdate=2007-12-03|work=[[New York Times]]}} ==Side projects and collaborations== Karen O and Nick Zinner both appear as guests on [[Tiny Masters of Today]]'s album ''[[Bang Bang Boom Cake]]''. The song was written via email and features Karen singing. In addition, Karen co-directed and all three band members were featured in the video for the group's "[[Hologram World]]" video. In 2009, the band appeared on a charity album ''[[War Child Presents Heroes]]'' with their version of [[The Ramones]]' song "[[Sheena Is a Punk Rocker]]". Zinner also contributed to the [[Bright Eyes (band)|Bright Eyes]]' record ''[[Digital Ash in a Digital Urn]]'' and performed with the band on tour. ===Soundtrack work=== For the movie ''[[Jackass 2]]'', Karen O collaborated with electronic artist [[Peaches (musician)|Peaches]] and [[Johnny Knoxville]] to record a track entitled "Backass"; for ''[[Jackass 3D]]'', she covered the ''[[Roger Alan Wade]]'' 's "If You're Gonna Be Dumb" under the alternative title of "If You're Gonna Be Dumb, You Gotta Be Tough".In 2007, Karen contributed vocals to a version of [[Bob Dylan]]'s "[[Highway 61 Revisited (song)|Highway 61 Revisited]]" for the ''[[I'm Not There]]'' movie soundtrack.{{cite web| url=http://stereogum.com/archives/new-karen-o-highway-61-revisited-stereogum-premier_006927.html| title=New Karen O â "Highway 61 Revisited" (Stereogum Premiere)| date=October 25, 2007| work=[[Stereogum]]| accessdate=2009-04-15}} She also appears on the soundtrack of the film ''[[Where The Wild Things Are (film)|Where The Wild Things Are]]'', directed by former boyfriend [[Spike Jonze]].{{cite web | url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2007/11/karen-o-is-where-the-wild-things-are.html | title =Karen O is Where the Wild Things Are | accessdate=2007-11-20 | author = Kasia Galazka| date =2007-11-20 | work=[[Paste Magazine]] }} In 2007, the song "Date With the Night" was featured in episode 1.05 of [[Skins (TV series)]], and is on the official soundtrack. Their song "Runaway" was also featured on the April 20, 2009 episode of ''Gossip Girl'' and on the Australian television show "Sea Patrol". "Sealings" appears on both ''[[Driver: Parallel Lines]]'' & [[Spider-Man 3 (soundtrack)|''Spider-Man 3'']] soundtracks. The song "Phenomena" featured on the film ''[[The Ruins (film)|The Ruins]]'' as the song of the ending credits. The "Little Vampire" remixed version of "Heads will Roll" features in [[Gran Turismo 5]] as in-game music. In the super bowl episode of Glee, "[[The Sue Sylvester Shuffle]]", the McKinley High School football team and the New Directions performed "Heads Will Roll" along with [[Michael Jackson]]'s "[[Thriller (song)|Thriller]]" for their halftime show. In March 2010 their song "Heads will Roll" was featured on a promo for the 4th season of the Showtime series The Tudors. ===The ''KO At Home'' demo leak=== On December 10, 2006, a home-recorded album titled ''[[KO at Home]]'' was leaked via an invite-only [[BitTorrent (protocol)|BitTorrent]] tracking site. The album, originally a personal gift to [[Dave Sitek]] of the NYC band [[TV on the Radio]], was discovered inside a suitcase Sitek owned, amongst the rubble from a New York apartment fire. The disc's 14 tracks and scan of the cover â a photograph of Karen O with a poem written by [[Oscar Wilde]] on the back â quickly spread. The music news site [[Stereogum]] broke the story of the leak{{cite web| url=http://stereogum.com/archives/mp3/karen-demo_004140.html| title= Karen (Dem)O| work=Stereogum| date=December 11, 2006| accessdate=2009-04-15}} the following morning and continued their coverage{{cite web| url=http://stereogum.com/archives/the-story-behind-the-karen-o-demo_004144.html| title=The Story Behind The Karen O Demo| date=December 11, 2006| accessdate=2009-04-15}} when Sitek lashed out at the fan who leaked the demos.{{cite web| url=http://youngliars.blogspot.com/2006_12_01_archive.html#39643304333086041| title=Blogpost about Karen O's demo leak| first=Dave| last=Sitek| authorlink=Dave Sitek| date=December 11, 2006|accessdate=2009-04-15}} Eventually Sitek followed up his comments with an apology letter.{{cite web| url=http://youngliars.blogspot.com/2006_12_01_archive.html#7815441358413327623| title=Apology letter| first=Dave| last=Sitek| authorlink=Dave Sitek| date=December 12, 2006|accessdate=2009-04-15}} Karen O's response to the leak was "[[shit happens]]" and although she was somewhat "grossed out," she offered advice on which of the mp3s she liked the best,{{cite web| url=http://www.dose.ca/photos/music/story.html?id=ffc20ba9-da25-4e03-b2cf-d7db526bee08&k=18318| title=Karen O on Demo Leak: 'Shit Happens'| work=dose.ca| date=December 14, 2006| first=Heather| last=Adler| accessdate=2009-04-15}} namely the tracks "Pumpkin" and "Snakes and Worms". ===Head Wound City=== [[Nick Zinner]] also collaborates in a [[mathcore]]/[[thrashcore]] [[supergroup (music)|supergroup]] [[Head Wound City]]. Other members of the group are [[Jordan Blilie]] ([[Past Lives (band)|Past Lives]], The Blood Brothers), [[Cody Votolato]] ([[Jaguar Love]], [[The Blood Brothers (band)|The Blood Brothers]]), [[Justin Pearson]] ([[Holy Molar]], [[The Locust]]) and [[Gabe Serbian]] (The Locust, Holy Molar). Their debut [[Head Wound City EP|self-titled EP]] was released in 2005. ==Grammy nominations== {{awards table}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2004 || ''[[Fever to Tell]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1484284/20040112/white_stripes.jhtml|title=White Stripes To Perform At Grammy Awards|first=Joe|last=D'Angelo|date=January 12, 2004|accessdate=April 29, 2010|publisher=MTV}} || [[Grammy Award for Best Alternative Music Album|Best Alternative Music Album]]|| {{nom}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2007 || ''[[Show Your Bones]]''{{cite web|url=http://www2.grammy.com/GRAMMY_Awards/49th_show/list.aspx#05|title=49th Annual Grammy Awards Winners List|publisher=Grammy Awards|accessdate=April 29, 2010}} || [[Grammy Award for Best Alternative Music Album|Best Alternative Music Album]]|| {{nom}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2010 || ''[[It's Blitz!]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/beyonce/48701|title=Grammy nominations 2010 announced â Beyonce, Lady Gaga, MGMT shortlisted|accessdate=April 29, 2010|date=December 3, 2009|work=NME|publisher=IPC Media}}|| [[Grammy Award for Best Alternative Music Album|Best Alternative Music Album]] || {{nom}} |- {{end}} ==MTV Video Music Award nomination== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year || Category || Music video || Result |- |style="text-align:center;" rowspan="4"| 2004 || Best Art Direction In A Video || style="text-align:center;" rowspan="4"| Maps || {{nom}} |- | Best Editing In A Video || {{nom}} |- | Best Cinematography In A Video || {{nom}} |- | MTV2 Award || {{nom}} |- | 2009 || Breakthrough Video || Heads Will Roll || {{nom}} |} ==Discography== {{main|Yeah Yeah Yeahs discography}} * ''[[Fever to Tell]]'' (2003) * ''[[Show Your Bones]]'' (2006) * ''[[It's Blitz!]]'' (2009) ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Yeah Yeah Yeahs}} *[http://www.yeahyeahyeahs.com/ Official Yeah Yeah Yeahs Site] *{{MySpace|yeahyeahyeahs|Yeah Yeah Yeahs}} *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/music/artists/584c04d2-4acc-491b-8a0a-e63133f4bfc4 BBC artist page] *[http://pinstand.com/pins/yyy.html YYY Pins], early list of links to interviews, photos, etc. *[http://www.exclaim.ca/articles/multiarticlesub.aspx?csid1=79&csid2=778&fid1=1003 "Yeah Yeah Yeahs: The Love Cats"], ''[[Exclaim!]]'' {{Yeah Yeah Yeahs}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Yeah Yeah Yeahs}} [[Category:Yeah Yeah Yeahs| ]] [[Category:Alternative rock groups from New York]] [[Category:American indie rock groups]] [[Category:Musical groups established in 2000]] [[Category:Touch and Go Records artists]] [[Category:Interscope Records artists]] [[Category:Polydor Records artists]] [[Category:Modular Recordings artists]] [[ca:Yeah Yeah Yeahs]] [[da:Yeah Yeah Yeahs]] [[de:Yeah Yeah Yeahs]] [[es:Yeah Yeah Yeahs]] [[fr:Yeah Yeah Yeahs]] [[gl:Yeah Yeah Yeahs]] [[ko:ì ì ìì¤]] [[hr:Yeah Yeah Yeahs]] [[it:Yeah Yeah Yeahs]] [[he:Yeah Yeah Yeahs]] [[ka:Yeah Yeah Yeahs]] [[nl:Yeah Yeah Yeahs]] [[ja:ã¤ã¼ã»ã¤ã¼ã»ã¤ã¼ãº]] [[no:Yeah yeah yeahs]] [[pl:Yeah Yeah Yeahs]] [[pt:Yeah Yeah Yeahs]] [[ro:Yeah Yeah Yeahs]] [[ru:Yeah Yeah Yeahs]] [[sr:Yeah Yeah Yeahs]] [[fi:Yeah Yeah Yeahs]] [[sv:Yeah Yeah Yeahs]]
